Precise design and synthesis of supramolecules with cavities are of vital importance for developing novel porous heterogeneous catalysts but remain great challenges. Herein, taking advantage of configuration-controllable capability, four bulky and rigid EMind scaffolds were peripherally installed onto photocatalytic porphyrin core to construct metalloporphyrin with semi-opened cavity as single molecular heterogeneous catalyst. The extremely low solubility in organic solvents and incapability of close packing endowed this kind of material with intriguing intramolecular porosity and heterogenization in catalysis. Among them, the porphyrin(Fe) molecule engaging the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts possessed good stability, recyclability and high efficiency to oxidize various sulfides into sulfoxides in gram-scale, attributable to the designed novel structure. The key reactive oxygen species was demonstrated to be superoxide anion radicals in the established catalytic system. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Four bulky and rigid EMind scaffolds were readily installed peripherally onto porphyrin core to construct metalloporphyrin with semi-opened cavity as novel single molecular heterogeneous catalyst for highly recyclable and selective photocatalytic oxidation of sulfides to sulfoxides. Keywords Porphyrin Photocatalysis Heterogeneous Semi-opened cavity Oxidation of sulfide Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Heterogeneous catalysis has been attracted more and more attentions since it is of vital importance and thus very appealing for practical applications such as industrial fine chemical productions [1–8]. The most advantageous attributes of the heterogeneous catalysts are the recyclability and easy separation from the reaction mixtures by filtration or centrifugation compared to the traditional homogeneous catalysts, which are unrecyclable and bear insurmountable energy consumption during the purification processes [9–13]. Promising strategies to develop heterogeneous catalysts are including anchoring active catalytic sites onto the supports such as dendrimers [14,15], inorganic nanoparticles [16–19], and crystalline covalent organic frameworks (COFs) and metal‒organic frameworks (MOFs) [20–23], but suffering from the tedious synthesis, agglomeration and unsatisfactory stability. Hitherto, an untouched way is to utilize small molecules with catalytic sites which are functionalized with bulky and rigid ligands to prevent close packing and create potential intra/inter-molecular voids for efficient diffusion of the reactants. Compounds with intramolecular cavities represent a burgeoning subject area in supramolecular chemistry and show intriguing applications across diverse fields such as catalysis [24,25], separation [26,27], adsorption [28,29], etc. In particular, these compounds are characterized by artificial nanospaces, allowing them to serve as nanoreactors or hosts. For the past decades, a few landmark molecules have been harnessed for these purposes, including cucurbiturils [30,31], calixarenes [32,33], and cyclodextrins [34,35]. Design and synthesis of such molecules as catalysts still remain great challenges. Recently, porphyrins have gained significant interest to use as key building blocks for supramolecules in virtue of the large co-planar structure and easily tailorable catalytic metal sites [36,37]. In addition, the exceptional light absorption of porphyrins endows them with promising photocatalytic properties and makes them appealing for building photocatalytic systems [38,39]. Therefore, as a proof of concept, we conceived of synthesizing single molecules with novel suprastructures as heterogeneous catalysts. As shown in Scheme 1 , taking advantage of the rigid and bulky EMind (1,1,7,7-tetraethyl-3,3,5,5-tetramethyl-s-hydrindacene) unit with configuration controllable capability and utilizing porphyrin as the core, single molecules with semi-opened voids could be synthesized by simple condensation of aldehyde with amine groups. It is notable that the reported EMind ligand has been demonstrated as a protecting group for stabilizing various active species but not used for building suprastructures [40–42]. These robust supramolecules could show low solubility in traditional reaction solvents and be unable to close packing, making them in an amorphous and porous state in the catalytic reactions. Compared to the porous COF and MOF catalysts, this design possesses great merits of easy synthesis and high stability as a new kind of recyclable heterogeneous catalysts. The artificial intra/inter-molecular nanospaces could facilitate the dynamic exchange of the substrates and products, enabling enhanced catalytic efficiency. On the other hand, sulfoxide compounds play a significant role across various fields, including fine chemicals [43,44], materials science [45,46], and organic synthesis [47,48], etc. The broad applications have spurred growing interest in the synthesis of sulfoxides, which are generally synthesized by oxidation of the thioethers. Herein, we employed the single molecular heterogeneous catalyst (SMHC) for photocatalytic oxidation of various sulfides to the corresponding sulfoxides. The expected heterogeneous characteristics, good recyclability, enhanced photocatalytic activity, and gram-scale production were demonstrated to show the advanced potentials in practical applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and solvents The reagents and solvents commercially available were used directly without further purification. The anhydrous solvents used were ultra-dry with moisture content below 30 ppm. The synthetic details of the reported compound EMindNH2 and characterization methods can be found in the supplementary material. 2.2 Synthesis of tetra(EMind)iminoporphyrin (EMindTPP) Tetrakis(4-formylphenyl)porphyrin (TFPP, 1.0 mmol, 0.72 g), EMindNH2 (4.2 mmol, 1.44 g), and 1, 2-dichloroethane (DCE, 50 mL) were sequentially added to a 100 mL single-necked flask. Subsequently, trifluoroacetic acid (TFA, 42 µL) was introduced into the reaction mixture. The resulting mixture was heated and stirred under reflux at 90 °C for 48 h. The reaction mixture was neutralized using aqueous NaOH solution (20 %). The resultant mixture was washed over brine, extracted with dichloromethane (DCM, 3 × 50 mL), and dried using anhydrous Na2SO4. The organic layer was concentrated to yield a crude product as brownish-red solid. The pure target compound was obtained by recrystallization from CH3CN/DCM (100:1) mixed solvents as a purplish-red solid (1.94 g, 96 % yield). 2.3 Synthesis of tetra(EMind)iminoporphyrin-M(II) (EMindTPPM) Under nitrogen atmosphere, EMindTPP (0.25 mmol), M(OAc)2 (M = Mn, Cu, Zn, Ni, Co, 8.0 equiv., 2.0 mmol), CHCl3 (40 mL), and MeOH (10 mL) were sequentially added to a 100 mL double-necked flask. The reaction mixture was heated to 60 °C and stirred under reflux for 12 h. After concentrated to remove all the volatiles, the reaction mixture was extracted with DCM (3 × 30 mL) and washed with brine. The organic layer was dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The resulting solid was washed thoroughly with EtOH and dried under vacuum to afford the target products (yield 86 % ∼ 98 %). 2.4 General procedure for photocatalytic oxidation of sulfides catalyzed by EMindTPPFe The representative procedure for photocatalytic oxidation of sulfide: A mixture of EMindTPPFe (0.96 μmol, 2 mg) and MeOH (1.0 mL) was added to a 10 ml Pyrex tube. After ultrasonication for 3 min, a homogeneous suspension was formed, followed by the addition of sulfide (0.3 mmol). The mixture was then bubbled gently with O2 gas flow for 3 min and sealed. Subsequently, the Pyrex tube was fixed and exposed to irradiation by a blue light-emitting diode (LED) lamp (420 nm, 25 W) at room temperature for 12 h. After the reaction, the EMindTPPFe catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed over MeOH (3 × 0.5 mL). The resultant solid catalyst was used directly for the next cycle. The conversion and selectivity of the sulfide oxidation were examined by gas chromatography mass spectroscopy (GC‒MS) analysis. 2.5 General procedure for photocatalytic oxidation of thioanisole in grame scale catalyzed by a variety of porphyrin catalyst The representative procedure for photocatalytic oxidation of thioanisole in gram scale: A mixture of porphyrin catalyst (0.11 mmol) and MeOH (30 mL) was added to a 50 ml Pyrex tube. After ultrasonication for 3 min, to the homogeneous suspension was added thioanisole (9.0 mmol, 1.12 g). The mixture was then bubbled gently with O2 gas flow for 3 min and sealed. Subsequently, the Pyrex tube was fixed and exposed to irradiation by a blue LED lamp (420 nm, 25 W) at room temperature for 20 h. After the reaction, the porphyrin catalyst was separated by filtration and washed over MeOH (3 × 0.5 mL). The resultant solid catalyst could be directly used for the next photocatalytic reactions with negligible activity decline. The product was separated from the concentrated crude product by column chromatography to give the isolated yield. Notably, for the catalysis giving quantitative conversion and over 99 % selective (e.g., thioanisole), the pure product could be obtained by simply concentration of the filtrate and dried under vacuum. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of the EMindTPPFe The synthesis of EMindTPP and EMindTPPFe was depicted in Schemes 2 and 3 , respectively. The EMindTPP was readily synthesized by condensation of the TPFF with EMindNH2 under reflux for 48 h. The EMindTPP could be harvested in 96 % yield after simple crystallization as purplish-red solid. Metalation of the EMindTPP was easily achieved by refluxing the EMindTPP with different metal sources M(OAc)2 (M = Mn, Cu, Zn, Ni, Co) and purified by solvent washing in up to 98 % yield. As a representative, the successful formation of the EMindTPPFe was verified by Fourier transform infrared (FT‒IR) spectroscopy with those of EMindNH2, TFPP, EMindTPP for comparison. In the spectra of EMindTPP and EMindTPPFe, the peaks at 1690 cm‒1 and 3400‒3500 cm‒1 corresponding to CO and NH2 groups respectively completely disappeared, while a distinct peak at 1640 cm‒1 indicative of imine (CN) formation was clearly evident, confirming the successful condensation reaction to form Schiff-base (Fig 1 a). Additionally, a weak peak at 3312 cm‒1 in the spectrum of EMindTPP ascribed to the characteristic pyrrole N‒H stretching entirely disappeared in the spectrum of EMindTPPFe, suggesting the chelation of Fe in EMindTPP. The embedment of Fe(II) ion in the porphyrin framework was examined by high-resolution X‒ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 1b, it was revealed that two distinct peaks of binding energies at 711.2 eV and 724.7 eV were assignable to the Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, respectively [49]. The C 1s and N 1s XPS spectra shown in Fig. S1 were also well assigned which were in good agreement with the reported data [50–53]. More solid evidence of the successful synthesis of this single EMindTPPFe molecule was from the high-resolution mass spectrum, showing a well-matched molecular weight of 2073.057 (Fig. S2). It is notable that the 1H NMR spectra of these single molecules could be well resolved to be consistent with the molecular structures except for the EMindTPPM (M = Fe, Cu, Mn) which were not available due to the paramagnetism. The designed intra/inter-molecular cavity characteristic of EMindTPPFe was investigated by using N2 sorption on its collected powder. The N2 sorption isotherm curve of EMindTPPFe at 77 K is shown in Fig. 2 a. The gas adsorption features a slow increase at low pressures (0 < P/P 0 < 0.1), which gradually increases and reaches an uptake of 90 mL g‒1. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of EMindTPPFe was determined to be 42 m2 g‒1, while the aperture distribution diagram shown in the inset of Fig. 2a manifests a broad distribution from 1.8 to 20 nm with a maximum peak at 2.7 nm, revealing disordered pores artificially created by randomly non-close packing. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images reveal that EMindTPPFe exhibits a blocky morphology with uniformly dispersed C, N, Fe elements (Fig. S3‒S4). It is interesting that evaporation of the DCM solution of EMindTPPFe readily led to bulk material after aggregation with uniform micrometer pores or channels which could be resulted from the intrinsic intra/inter-molecular cavity characteristic, making a novel heterogeneous porous system (Fig. 2b). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed to evaluate the thermal stability and showed 5 % weight loss at 217 °C (Fig. S5). The photophysical properties are intriguing and of vital importance for this kind of porphyrin molecules. The UV–vis spectrum of the EMindTPPFe in DCM solution is shown in Fig. S6. The presence of a Soret band at 422 nm and four typical Q bands at 518–648 nm indicates the existence of porphyrin moiety. The solid-state ultraviolet-visible diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV‒vis DRS) of EMindTPPFe spans in a range of 200 to 800 nm, featuring five distinct porphyrin characteristic peaks located at 484–649 nm (Fig. 3 a). The Mott‒Schottky curves, recorded at frequencies of 1500 Hz, 2000 Hz, and 2500 Hz, are presented in Fig. 3b. The positive slope of these curves indicates that EMindTPPFe functions as an n‒type semiconductor, with an estimated conduction band minimum (CBM) potential of ‒0.05 V vs. normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) [54–56]. From the Tauc plot of EMindTPPFe (inset of Fig. 3a), the optical bandgap is calculated to be 1.81 eV, and thus the valence band maximum (VBM) is calculated to be 1.76 V vs. NHE (Fig. 3b). Under illumination from a 420 nm LED light source, EMindTPPFe exhibits significant photocurrent responsiveness, generating a transient photocurrent with a rapid increase in current intensity (Fig. 3c). The photocurrent remains stable during a continuous on-off lamp cycle lasting 500 s, indicating effective separation of electron‒hole pairs under light irradiation. Furthermore, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements for EMindTPPFe, EMindTPPZn, and EMindTPP reveal that EMindTPPFe exhibits lower resistance, facilitating faster charge transfer (Fig. 3d). The fluorescence test showing very weak intensity confirms that EMindTPPFe could serve as an effective photocatalyst (Fig. S7). 3.2 Photocatalysis for selective oxidation of sulfides The photocatalytic performances of the catalysts with different central metals were first evaluated by using thioanisole as model substrate without addition of any sacrificial agents or co-catalysts (Table 1 ). Among all the metalloporphyrin catalyst, the EMindTPPFe catalyst showed the best performances, i.e., 100 % conversion with 99.8 % selectivity under the same reaction condition. The conversion of the catalysts gradually decreased in the order of Fe > Zn > Ni > Co > Cu > Mn (Table 1, entries 1‒6). Notably, in the absence of metal embedment, the parent EMindTPP showed 95 % conversion with 89.8 % selectivity, indicating the central metal can profoundly regulate the photocatalytic performances (Table 1, entry 7). Furthermore, the use of air instead of oxygen atmosphere resulted in an evident decrease in conversion to 83 %, confirming that the reaction is an aerobic oxidation process (Table 1, entry 8). The light sources ranging from 365 nm to 620 nm were examined and irradiative wavelength of 420 nm close to the absorption maximum of EMindTPPFe (422 nm) showed the highest efficiency (Fig. S8). The reaction solvents were also screened to show that the optimal solvent is methanol in overall consideration (Table S1). The catalytic activity of EMindTPPFe(II) with EMindTPPZn(II) and EMindTPP for comparison was examined using 4-chlorothioanisole and 4-methoxythioanisole as substrate models (Fig. 4 ). Under the identical reaction condition, both the electron-withdrawing group (‒Cl) and electron-donating group (‒OMe) on phenyl group of the thioanisole led to both conversion and selectivity exceeding 99 % when catalyzed by EMindTPPFe(II). In contrast, the yields of the oxidation to sulfoxides catalyzed by EMindTPP and EMindTPPZn(II) was markedly inferior. These findings indicate that EMindTPPFe(II) exhibits exceptional selectivity and high efficiency in facilitating the conversion of organic molecules during photocatalytic reactions. The enhanced performance could be attributed to the superior transport efficiency of photo-generated charge carriers [57]. Under the optimized conditions, to further comprehensively assess the efficiency of EMindTPPFe, a variety of traditional sulfide compounds were employed as substrates for the established photocatalytic oxidation system (Table 2 ). All phenyl sulfides, alkyl sulfides, and cyclic sulfides could be efficiently oxidized to their corresponding sulfoxides. Notably, thioanisole exhibited a remarkable conversion and selectivity of 100 % (Table 2, entry 1). Sulfides bearing electron-donating groups underwent oxidation more readily than those with electron-withdrawing substituents (Table 2, entries 2‒4). Thioanisoles substituted with ‒F, ‒Cl, ‒Br, or ‒I required prolonged oxidation time; the reaction involving with ‒I substituent was faster than those involving ‒F, ‒Cl or ‒Br (Table 2, entries 4‒9) due to its weak electron-donating ability. It is worth mentioning that amino substituent did not have any adverse impact on this photocatalytic oxidation, while the para NO2-substituted thioanisole required a longer time of 16 h with lower selectivity of 86.7 % for oxidation (Table 2, entries 10‒11) [58,59]. The diphenyl sulfide is generally very difficult to be oxidized. In this oxidative system, the oxidation of diphenyl sulfide also gave 22.3 % conversion after 16 h (Table 2, entry 12). Notably, alkyl, longer alkyl and cyclic alkyl substitutions could boost the oxidation, making the oxidation complete and affording quantitative conversion within 4.5 h (Table 2, entries 13‒17). The stability and reusability are the most innovative features of this concept for SMHCs. After catalysis, the EMindTPPFe catalyst could be readily recovered by centrifugation and washed over MeOH solution with minimal loss. As we expected, the photocatalytic oxidation of thioanisole well maintained quantitative conversion and over 98 % selectivity after testing for five cycles (Fig. 5 a), indicating that the catalytic activity of EMindTPPFe remained unchanged. FT‒IR and UV‒vis spectra were performed for the recovered EMindTPPFe catalyst. The identical spectra suggested the remarkable photostability of the EMindTPPFe (Fig. S9). To confirm that this reaction is heterogeneous, an obvious Tyndall effect was observed for the reaction mixture with EMindTPPFe catalyst; there was no Tyndall effect of the reaction mixture without adding the catalyst (Fig. S10). Moreover, hot filtration control experiments showed that the yield slightly increased and remained invariable after the catalyst was removed, further indicating the heterogeneous characteristic of this photocatalysis (Fig. S11). The almost linear fitting of the time dependent yields for the kinetic tests illuminated that the reaction followed a zero-order kinetics as other reported heterogeneously photocatalytic oxidation (Fig. S11) [60–64]. To verify the potential for practical application, photocatalytic oxidation catalyzed by EMindTPPFe was carried out in gram scale. The catalysis preserved persistent outstanding conversion and selectivity and yielded the sulfoxide in gram scale and the recovered EMindTPPFe catalyst exhibited negligible mass loss and activity decline, demonstrating the advantages of this kind of SMHCs. In addition, the catalytic activity of EMindTPPFe was evaluated by comparison with traditional Fe(II) porphyrins, including TPPFe, 4-ClTPPFe, 4-BrTPPFe, 4-NO2TPPFe, 4-OCH3TPPFe, 4-COOHTPPFe and 4-PyTPPFe, in the photocatalytic oxidation of thioanisole in the gram scale. The reaction was carried out using a 25 W LED light at 420 nm for 20 h. The products were thereafter separated by column chromatography to determine the isolated yields (Fig. 5b). Without the EMind functionalization, the traditional Fe(II) photocatalysts such as TPPFe not only showed higher solubility in the reaction solvent which required tedious column chromatography during the purification process, but also exhibited evident decline of the photocatalytic activity which probably caused by the photobleaching. The notably lower yields (51 % ∼ 69 %) achieved by the traditional catalysts could be attributed to the photodegradation arising from prolonged reaction time. Moreover, the intra/inter-molecular cavity of EMindTPPFe could facilitate fast diffusion of the reactants into the porphyrin photoactive sites. 3.3 The photocatalytic mechanism of EMindTPPFe To investigate the mechanism of photocatalytic oxidation of sulfides by EMindTPPFe, thioanisole was used as substrate and a series of quenching experiments were conducted with various scavengers to verify the reactive oxygen species (ROS) generated during the oxidation (Fig. 6 a). When argon gas was used instead of oxygen, only a minimal yield of 8 % was detected, indicating that oxygen is essential for generating ROS. The addition of benzoquinone (p-BQ) as superoxide (O2 •‒) scavenger or AgNO3 as electron (e‒) scavenger resulted in a significant decrease in the conversion rate, demonstrating the crucial roles of O2 •‒ and e⁻ in the reaction. In addition, when hole (h⁺) scavengers such as KI and triethanolamine (TEOA) were introduced, the yield dramatically decreased, suggesting the involvement of h⁺ in the reaction. In contrast, the addition of singlet oxygen (1O2) scavengers, such as 1,4-diazabicyclo[2, 2, 2]octane (DABCO) or 1, 3-diphenylisobenzofuran (DPBF), had little impact on the yield. Moreover, when CD3OD was used instead of CH3OH as the solvent to extend the lifetime of 1O2, a slight decrease of the yield was attained. These quenching experiments indicated that O2 •‒ plays a primary role in the photocatalytic oxidation process, while 1O2 may contribute in a little capacity. To unambiguously verify the presence of O2 •‒ species in the photocatalytic reaction, 5, 5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) was used as a capture agent. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra clearly showed the strong radical signal which could be assigned for the DMPO‒O2 •‒ adduct after light illumination for 10 min while no signal appeared without illumination (Fig. 6b). This indicated the reaction light illumination of the catalytic system generated the O2 •‒ species which is typical as ROS in the photocatalytic process. Based on these research results and previous reports [65], the plausible reaction mechanism for the photocatalytic oxidation of thioanisole by EMindTPPFe was proposed (Scheme 4 ). Initially, under the illumination of a 420 nm blue LED, EMindTPPFe absorbs visible light, generating pairs of photo-induced e‒ and h+. Subsequently, e⁻ is transferred from the HOMO of EMindTPPFe to the LUMO and combines with O2 to form O2 •‒. Meanwhile, the h⁺ oxidizes thioanisole to form a thioanisole radical cation, which subsequently reacts with O2 •‒ to produce a dipole peroxythioanisole intermediate [66,67]. Finally, this intermediate takes a proton (H⁺) from MeOH solvent, yielding the product phenyl methyl sulfoxide and H2O. 4 Conclusions In summary, leveraging a unique steric bulky scaffold EMind, supramolecular porphyrin with semi-opened cavities was readily synthesized via simple condensation reaction. After metal embedment, the EMindTPPFe has active photocatalytic porphyrin(Fe) core with superior stability. The prohibited close packing of the porphyrin(Fe) endows its aggregated state with intriguing dynamic porosity, that is, heterogenization of the porphyrin(Fe) molecule to a novel single molecular heterogeneous photocatalyst. The porosity and heterogeneity of EMindTPPFe have been verified and allow it to serve as novel efficient, recyclable photocatalyst for highly selective oxidation of a variety of sulfides to the corresponding sulfoxides. The apparently superior efficiency of EMindTPPFe compared with the homogeneous unfunctionalized metalloporphyrin catalysts could be attributable to the confinement of reactants in the artificial intermolecular pores. This seminal work will not only provide distinctive concepts for designing new nontraditional heterogeneous catalysts but also establish novel catalytic system in practical applications. coredata.dc:description: Precise design and synthesis of supramolecules with cavities are of vital importance for developing novel porous heterogeneous catalysts but remain great challenges. Herein, taking advantage of configuration-controllable capability, four bulky and rigid EMind scaffolds were peripherally installed onto photocatalytic porphyrin core to construct metalloporphyrin with semi-opened cavity as single molecular heterogeneous catalyst. The extremely low solubility in organic solvents and incapability of close packing endowed this kind of material with intriguing intramolecular porosity and heterogenization in catalysis. Among them, the porphyrin(Fe) molecule engaging the advantages of both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts possessed good stability, recyclability and high efficiency to oxidize various sulfides into sulfoxides in gram-scale, attributable to the designed novel structure. The key reactive oxygen species was demonstrated to be superoxide anion radicals in the established catalytic system.

coredata.dc:title: Heterogenization of porphyrin as single molecular heterogeneous catalyst for highly recyclable and selective photocatalytic oxidation of sulfides
